content: I am aware that I sound pedantic at times, and I do apologise for that (while I'm at it, I'll also apologise for my use of British spelling, which I've adopted mainly to annoy two specific readers, who know who they are). In my defence, I can only point to a constitutional inablility to resist commenting on the mistakes, inaccuracy and poor writing that I see almost daily in the press.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , for example. She's apparently quite well known over here, though I had never heard of her until I recently started reading the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: (because I'm lazy, and there's so much easy grist in its pages).

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Since I've first become aware of her - through noting with amusement her

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: - I've learned that she is in fact past editor of something called the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: , which purports to bring erotic writing to the intelligentsia. More recently, she's been pressed into service as a judge of the prestigious Booker Prize for literature, as she

tag: html body text div div div p a span

content: Incidentally, the first of those last three links is almost worth the Â£1 it costs to access. In it, Pelling complains of suffering from "

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: tristesse" - a depression, tinged with guilt, that afflicts literary prize givers after they make an award. In Rowan's case, the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: was particularly bad, since she was the very, very most important judge of all - the "Florida" of judges, as she put it (referring to that state's role in the 2000 US elections).

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: I admit to wondering what she was going to write about once the Booker had been awarded, given the frequency with which she addressed that topic (and, more importantly, her role as judge). In fact, I was afraid that the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: would weigh so heavily upon her that she'd be forced to give up writing entirely.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Thankfully I needn't have worried - she reappears in the pages of yesterday's

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p em span
content: Love for Sale: A Global History of Prostitution

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: . The post-Booker Pelling has lost none of her punch, and she mercilessly hits the reader with one shot after another.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Wasting no time, she lets us have it right from the opening bell, with a couple of glancing jabs:

tag: html body text div div div blockquote p span
html body text div div div blockquote p em span
content: Legend has it that the Innuits have several hundred words for snow

tag: html body text div div div blockquote p span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: ," the opening combination isn't terribly painful - though including as it does the jarring variant spelling "

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: " it does impart a bit of a sting.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: But the opening jabs soften us up for this:

tag: html body text div div div blockquote p em span
content: "In the Hindu kingdoms of India in the last centuries BC, there were more than 300 different Sanskrit words for prostitute. I suppose that amply illustrates the cultural differences between people of hot and cold climes."

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Of course, it illustrates exactly nothing at all, not least because the first half of the comparison is

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , author of the book being reviewed, will no doubt be irritated that his factual nugget is sullied by the juxtaposition with one that's been so frequently debunked.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Second paragraph. The hapless reader is hit with:

tag: html body text div div div blockquote p em span
content: "Ringal's comprehensive study of turning tricks is equally compelling in its broader picture, whisking the reader from the temple prostitutes of Mesopotamia to the New York Mayfair Madam ..."

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Who is this 'Mayfair Madam', one wonders? Ms. Pelling, like her headline writer, seems to think that we'll all get the reference, but I've never heard of her. Either I don't know enough about prostitutes, or Rowan is inaccurately referring to the

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , who was all over the New York papers in the mid-80s.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Although it's distressing to imagine the former

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: editor making such an error, it is again no knockout punch in and of itself - but we're feeling just a tad woozy so early into the column.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div blockquote p em span
content: "He points out that Polynesian women, for example, have almost no concept of selling their favours when they can bestow them freely where they please and without censor."

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: ! Ouch - that one hurts! It might draw only a wince if seen in a freshman essay, but from the "Florida of the Booker Prize" it draws blood - the reader, still reeling from the jabs just thrown, staggers.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Staggers, but carries gamely on - to the next paragraph:

tag: html body text div div div blockquote p em span
content: "Prostitutes enjoyed some form of legislative protection and paid taxes in civilisations ranging from Chandragupta's Indian empire of 4BC ..."

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: BC. But what difference does it make? The fight is lost - after four such shots in four paragraphs, the reader is well and truly on the ropes, with no choice but to assume a defensive posture - dreading the next error (logical, linguistic or factual), and doubting every single assertion that Ms. Pelling makes.

content: Ms. Pelling's "The Decadent Handbook" informs the decadence challenged among us "how to run a brothel, arouse your pets and rollerblade decadently". You may not see the connection immediately, but when you start charging by dog hours you'll be roller blading decadently all the way to the bank.
